---
slug: /171
title: "This Week In React #171: Expo, React Conf, React 19 preview, Next.js, React-Email, Storybook, Panda, Nexar, React-Query, TypeScript, Vocs, Skottie, Harmony, VisionOS..."
authors: [slorber, bndkt]
date: 01-24-2024
---
Hi everyone!

This week the official React conf has been announced. Co-hosted with Callstack, I hope for React Native to be well-covered! React 19 is coming, and we continue to get sneak peeks into upcoming features such as proper Web Components support. I wouldn't be surprised to see it being released during the conf alongside React Forget ğŸ¤.

segments.source_content: In other news, this week is full of interesting articles and releases, including Next.js, React-Emails...
The React Native world has woken up with an impressive Expo SDK 50 release, and Expo Router v3 becoming the very first universal full-stack React framework.

segments.source_content:
- Use Axiom's pre-built dashboard for an overview across all your Vercel logs and vitals, drill down to specific projects and deployments, and get insight on how functions are performing with a single click.
- [next-axiom](https://github.com/axiomhq/next-axiom) allows you to send logs and events from any part of your Next.js projects - client, edge, or server-side - without any special configuration.
- Easily send structured logs directly from your code and analyze them together with Vercel logs.

## âš›ï¸ React {#react}
[![Next.js App Router Training](/emails/issues/171/appRouterTraining.jpg)](https://nextjs-app-router-training.vercel.app/)
**[Next.js App Router Training](https://nextjs-app-router-training.vercel.app/)**

A playground with a quite exhaustive list of interactive demos about Next.js features. This is a great resource to understand how the Next.js App Router behaves by actually seeing it running with a convenient way to browse the related code.

- ğŸ’¸ [Accelerate your workflow with MightyMeld, a visual dev tool for React codebases. Drag, drop, click, and prompt your UI into place while you hand-code the rest of it.](https://www.mightymeld.com/?utm_source=thisweekinreact4&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=1&utm_content=top)

- ğŸ“œ [New client-side hooks coming to React 19](https://marmelab.com/blog/2024/01/23/react-19-new-hooks.html): Overview of new React hooks and APIs coming in the next major that you will be able to use without a framework.
- ğŸ“œ [The Query Options API](https://tkdodo.eu/blog/the-query-options-api): Dominik explains the advantages of removing React-Query overloads in v5, and using a single unified options object that you can reuse across all React-Query APIs thanks to TypeScript duck typing. The usage of a fancy TypeScript DataTag technique greatly improves the DX ğŸ™‰.
- ğŸ“œ [Panda v1 Roadmap](https://www.adebayosegun.com/blog/panda-v1-roadmap): the CSS-in-JS lib is progressing toward a v1 release. It has already optimized its runtime and integrated Lightning CSS. Remaining tasks include Panda Studio (to vizualize design tokens), opacity modifiers, container queries, config validationâ€¦
- ğŸ“œ [Wrangling Tuple Types](https://kyleshevlin.com/wrangling-tuple-types/): Explains why you might want to use TypeScript â€œas constâ€ while returning tuples from custom React hooks.
- ğŸ“œ [Build a Next.js app in Storybook with React Server Components and Mock Service Worker](https://storybook.js.org/blog/build-a-nextjs-app-with-rsc-msw-storybook/): The RSC support coming with Storybook 8 permits to develop a full Next.js app in isolation.
- ğŸ“œ [Build an app with Remix and Bun](https://sergiodxa.com/tutorials/build-an-app-with-remix-and-bun): Itâ€™s possible to use Bun at runtime, but for now you have to keep building the Remix app with Node.

segments.source_content: ## ğŸ“± React-Native {#react-native}
This weekâ€™s React Native news is compiled by Benedikt. Feedback, suggestions or news to share? Let me know on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/bndkt).

translations.zh-hant: æœ¬é€± React Native æ–°èç”± Benedikt ç·¨è­¯ã€‚å¦‚æœ‰å›é¥‹ã€å»ºè­°æˆ–æ–°èåˆ†äº«ï¼Ÿè«‹é€é [Twitter](https://twitter.com/bndkt) è¯ç¹«æˆ‘ã€‚

segments.source_content: [![Expo SDK 50](/emails/issues/171/expo50.jpg)](https://expo.dev/changelog/2024/01-18-sdk-50k)
**[Expo SDK 50](https://expo.dev/changelog/2024/01-18-sdk-50)**

Expo SDK 50 introduces Expo Dev Tools Plugins, comes with new SQLite and Camera APIs, and adds `@expo/fingerprint`, a new way to determine whether an updated JS bundle update is compatible with a given native build. This release also marks the [end of Webpack support](https://blog.expo.dev/webpack-support-in-expo-cli-is-now-deprecated-e9831d7eb631) in Expo, which is now deprecated in favor of Metro. The best and most convenient way to get up to speed on Expo 50 is probably to watch Simon rattle through it in about 15 minutes on [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=shaGaiwu4Fg).

segments.source_content: [![Expo Router v3](/emails/issues/171/router3.jpg)](https://expo.dev/changelog/2024/01-23-router-3)
**[Expo Router v3](https://expo.dev/changelog/2024/01-23-router-3)**

Along with Expo SDK 50, Expo Router v3 has been released. It brings lots of performance and stability improvements and comes with better docs. Most notably, there is now experimental support for building universal server endpoints with API Routes. Expo Router is now the very first universal, full-stack React framework!
